result.execSummary:
The defendant Jeffrey S. McKenzie was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse Assessments], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).
  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse Assessments], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).
  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse Assessments], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Pay court costs.   **NOTE: THE DEFENDANT IS ORDERED TO PAY ALL COURT OBLIGATIONS TO THE CLERK OF COURTS OFFICE.   Payment is due within 30 days.  If the Defendant cannot make the payment, he/she must report to the Clerk of Courts Office to set up a payment plan.  Failure to comply will result in other collection methods including a civil Judgment and/or suspension of your drivers license for one (1) year.  This judgment may be collected by income assignment if you fail to pay fines and costs as ordered.
--------------------------------------------

IT IS HEREBY ORDERED THAT the defendant's excess work release funds be applied to any & all outstanding Court obligations while serving his mandatory jail sentence.
--------------------------------------------

No alcohol.   No illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia.   No contact with victim without victim's and probation agent's consent. No contact with Kelly's parents, the Schweitzers'. No contact with his children without the authorization of G.A.L. in divorce case and permission of Probation Agent.
--------------------------------------------

Counseling as recommended by Probation Agent.   Provide biological specimen to state crime lab for DNA analysis, and pay DNA analysis surcharge.
--------------------------------------------

AODA assessment and follow through with recommendations.
--------------------------------------------
Pay restitution in the amount of $1,523.80 and restitution surcharge.

timeConds.notes: to commence on or before 11/17/2017 at 8:00 a.m. and WITH work release privileges.
Complete 40 hours of CSW for EACH year of probation ordered for a total of 120 hours of CSW; WITHOUT buyout option.

BAILIFFS:  Bob Nitka and Diane Mullins
8:31 am  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given.  
ADA Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Deft Jeffrey S. McKenzie in court with Atty Jonathan A. LaVoy.  
Matter is on to start day 2 of the trial but Court needs to address a matter before proceeding today.  
Court makes record as to events that took place yesterday.  Intern from DA office Kody Agnes, was seen speaking with a juror.  
8:36 am  Ashley Keough is sworn and testifies on exam of the Court.  
8:41 am  Juror Winger is brought into courtroom by Bailiff.  
8:42 am  Juror #6824 is sworn by Court and testifies on exam of the Court.  
8:43 am  Juror returns to Jury room.  
8:44 am  Ms. Keough confirms she saw this Juror at the McDonalds yesterday. Ms. McKenzie indicates she knows which Juror it was that was at McDonalds.  Ms. McKenzie thinks the Juror #2443.  
8:47 am  Kelly McKenzie is sworn and testifies on exam of Court.  
8:48 am  Questions of Ms. McKenzie by Atty LaVoy.  8:50 am  Witness excused.  
8:50 am  Court makes record with regard to e-mail from DA's office regarding whereabouts of Intern.  
8:51 am  Juror 2443 is present in Courtroom.  Response by Juror 2443 to Court's questions.  
8:54 am  Response by Juror 2443 to questions of both Atty Leusink and Atty LaVoy.  
8:55 am  Response by Juror 2443 to further questions of Court.  
8:56 am  Response by Juror 2443 to further question of Atty LaVoy.  
8:57 am  Court addresses Juror 2443 and explains that the Court is disqualifying him from serving on the jury at this time.  Court further explains he may not discuss the case with anyone until this case is over.  
8:58 am  Juror 2443 is excused from courtroom.  
8:59 am  Kody Agnes is sworn and testifies on exam of Court.  
9:05 am  Defendant interrupts testimony and is laughing.  Court admonishes defendant.  Defendant gets up moves to back of courtroom and sits next to victims.  
9:06 am  Security is in courtroom.   Court has concerns about defendant's sobriety and asks that he be administered a PBT.  PBT registers "0".  
9:09 am  Court asks Atty LaVoy if he has an explanation for defendant's behavior.  Deft's Aunt is present and Atty LaVoy spoke with her about concerns with deft having  brain or trauma issues.  
9:10 am  Atty LaVoy asks for time to speak with his client.  Court in recess.  
9:28 am  Court in session with Attys and defendant.  Atty LaVoy had a private conversation with his client and the State about his client's behavior in Court.  Atty LaVoy is questioning defendant's competency and requesting an evaluation.   Defendant's Aunt is present in Court and has provided collateral information with regard to Mr. McKenzie history.  Atty LaVoy has concerns as to whether he is mentally fit to proceed or can assist in his defense.  
9:31 am  Atty Leusink opposes the request of the defense.  
9:32 am  Outburst by Mr. McKenzie.  
9:32 am  Continued argument by Atty Leusink.  
9:33 am  Continued outbursts by Mr. McKenzie.  Court admonishes Mr. McKenzie and asks that he please be quiet.  
9:33 am  Response by Atty Leusink to Court's questions.  
9:34 am  Court has reason to doubt defendant's competency to proceed and makes further record.  Court Orders a competency evaluation.  Court will have to declare a mistrial.  Court finds there is probable cause that he violated his bond by having contact with Ms. McKenzie during these proceedings.  Court amends bond to add an additional $5,000 cash component to the bond.  Court orders defendant be taken into custody forthwith.  9:37 Court in recess.

Voir Dire
Juror Selection and Peremptory Challenges
Seating for 14

COURT REPORTERS:  
LINDA MATOSKA for the A.M. and 
GRETCHEN HOWE for the P.M.  
8:30 am  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given.  
ADA Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Deft Jeffrey S. McKenzie in court with Atty Jonathan A. LaVoy.  
Court addresses items with Attys before bringing jurors up.  
None of State's witnesses have any criminal convictions.  
Parties have a stipulation worked out as to the bail jumping charge which Atty Leusink reads into the record.  
Court has colloquy with Mr. McKenzie concerning the stipulation.  Court finds deft is freely, knowingly, voluntarily and intelligently waiving his right to a jury on those 2 elements of bail jumping.  
State has been able to come up with a transcript for the files.  Atty LaVoy has had a chance to review the transcript and listen to the recording at the same time.  Defense has no objection to State's transcript.  
8:38 am  Court in recess.  

OFF COURT RECORD AND IN JURY ASSEMBLY ROOM:  Clerk takes roll call of Jurors.  Clerk gives Oath of Competency to the Jurors.  Jurors are bought upstairs to Judge Drettwan's courtroom by Bailiffs.  Clerk seats 24 jurors in jury box.

3:18 pm  Response by Atty Leusink.  
3:18 pm  Court does not find there is currently a sufficient factual basis to inquire into self-defense.

3:30 pm  Court in session.  Jury seated in courtroom.

3:38 pm  Redirect by Atty Leusink.

3:52 pm  No cross by Atty LaVoy.  Witness excused.

Exhibit 2 marked. identified, offered, received & published.

4:42 pm  Objection by Atty LaVoy.  Court sustains objection.  No cross by Atty LaVoy.  Witness is excused.  
4:42 pm  Atty Leusink advises he has 1 witness coming tomorrow.  
4:42 pm  Jurors excused and asked to return tomorrow at 8:30 am.  
4:44 pm  Court makes record with regard to 
4:44 pm  Exhibits 9 through 13 are offered by Atty Leusink and received.  Court makes record identifying each document.  
4:45 pm  Response by Atty LaVoy as to witnesses he intends to call tomorrow.  
4:47 pm  Court in recess until tomorrow at 8:30 am


**TRANSCRIPT FILED 1/22/18: COURT REPORTER GRETCHEN HOWE**

2:05 pm  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given.  
ADA Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Defendant Jeffrey S. McKenzie in court with Atty Jonathan A. LaVoy.  
Matter is on today for a final pre-trial.  Both sides are ready to proceed to trial.  
Court has reviewed the Motion with regard to the 911 Call.  Court has reviewed the recorded 911 Call.  
Atty LaVoy agrees that the very beginning of the 911 Call would fall under a hearsay exception.  
Atty LaVoy is not objecting to the first minute of so of that call and makes argument.  
2:09 pm  Response by Atty Leusink.  If court does not find it is an excited utterance, he believes it would be admissible to show her credibility.  
2:12 pm  Court makes findings.  Court first needs to determine relevance under Sec. 904.01.  The 911 Call shows the victim's emotional state of mind and was extremely close in time to the alleged incident.  Court finds it is relevant evidence.  Court finds the probative value is not substantially outweighed by danger of unfair prejudice. Court finds it is admissible.  Court finds it is an excited utterance throughout the entire call.  Court the hearsay exceptions apply.  Court makes record as to portions of the Call that the Court does not want played.  State does not have a transcript of the 911 Call.  Court notes a lot of the call is not intelligible.  Court is going to seat 24 jurors for voir dire.  Discussion concerning prior records of any witnesses.  Court will convene at 8:30 am and jurors will be ready to come upstairs at 9:00 am.  2:24 pm  Atty Leusink makes record as to State's most recent offer.  Atty Lavoy acknowledges receipt of that offer and have reviewed that offer with his client.  He does not wish to accept the offer.  Court has colloquy with Mr. McKenzie who confirms his choice to reject the offer.  Each Atty will introduce their witnesses to jurors during voir dire.  Court makes record as to preliminary instructions that will be given to the jury.  Attys are no in agreement as to jurors being allowed to ask questions of witnesses.  Atty LaVoy states his client is stipulating to elements 1 and 2 of bail jumping.  Parties are going to attempt to reach a stipulation on this.  Court will allow Atty Leusink to look at this issue over the weekend and court will readdress this Monday morning.  
2:36 pm  Court in recess.

2:30 pm FINAL PER-TRIAL CALENDAR:  
ADA Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Defendant Jeffrey S. McKenzie in court with Atty Jonathan A. LaVoy.  
Atty LaVoy advises that defendant's prior counsel, Atty Flynn, is no longer with his firm.  
Atty LaVoy has been fully briefed on this case.  There is no resolution.  
Court advises parties this will remain on the calendar as the #2 case for trial.  
Atty LaVoy states Atty Flynn filed a 911 Motion that has not yet been heard.  
Court asks State to provide recording by the end of the day on July 14th.  
Court will then address this at a Final Pre-trial on July 21, 2017 at 2:00 pm
Final pre-trial scheduled for July 21, 2017 at 02:00 pm.
Atty LaVoy
DA Service Fees Invoice #17-532               $160.00

2:30 pm FINAL PRE-TRIAL CALENDAR:   
ADA Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Defendant Jeffrey S. McKenzie in court with attorney Jennifer Flynn. 
This case is scheduled for trial on Monday but Court explains it is being bumped from the trial calendar by another case that will be proceeding to trial.  New FPT and JT will be scheduled.  The Court that this is scheduled for a Miranda-Goodchild hearing tomorrow morning.  Attorneys make a record.  State would not use any statements of the defendant that were made to law enforcement in its case in chief.  Discussion between Court and Attorneys.  Court will cancel tomorrow's motion hearing.  New trial dates are scheduled with the Attorneys.  
Final pre-trial scheduled for July 5, 2017 at 02:30 pm.  
Jury trial scheduled for July 24, 2017 at 08:30 am. 

3:52 pm  Case recalled.  Same appearances.  Court inquires of the parties whether they would be willing to proceed to trial on Monday.  There's a possibility that the Court's #1 case for trial on Monday may not be able to go.  The Attorneys on the McKenzie case confirm that that would be prepared to go to trial on Monday.  Court would have its Clerk advise the Attorneys no late than tomorrow afternoon whether they will go or be bumped.  Court will ask that the Jurors be prepared to be brought up to the courtroom by 10:00 am Monday morning.  This would allow the Court to address any further pre-trial issues with the parties.  Jurors will not be allowed to ask questions of jurors as the Attys do not have an agreement on this.  Record is made by the Court as to the preliminary instructions it will give to the jury.  There will be 2 alternate jurors seated.  The State is to run the records for any potential witness and this will be discussed Monday morning.  Court will enter an exclusionary order with regard to witnesses.  The State's Court Officer and the victim can remain in the courtroom.  The witnesses can be present in the courtroom during voir dire so that they can be introduced to the jurors.  Court will have the State make a record on Monday morning as to any offers that have been made and rejected by the defense.  Discussion between Attys and Court concerning "911" call.  Atty Leusink would like an opportunity to discuss this with Atty Flynn and they may be able to narrow it down on Monday morning.  Court in recess.
Supplemental
Defendant's Request to Preclude 911 Call
03/31/2017 letter from ADA Matthew Leusink
DA Service Fees Invoice #17-363             $160.00
Defense

10:46 am  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given.  
ADA Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Defendant Jeffrey S. McKenzie in court with attorney Jennifer Flynn.  
Matter is before the Court for a number of motions that have been filed by the defense.  
Court will start with the Motions in Limine.  
1) - State is in agreement with this; Atty Leusink designates his court officer; and requests victim be allowed to be present; Court will enter exclusion order with regard to other witnesses; Witnesses may be in courtroom to be introduced to jurors during voir dire but would then be excluded; 
3)  Other acts - no objection by the State;  
5)  Reference to "victim" in presence of jury.  Argument by Atty Flynn.  Argument by Atty Leusink.  Court denies motion to have Court prohibit any reference by the State to K.M. as the victim.  Court does not believe this would be unfairly prejudicial.  
6)  A request for an Order prohibiting State from introducing any evidence of the pursuit/chase.  Argument by Atty Flynn.  Atty Leusink has nothing to add to his written response.  Court denies this Motion in Limine.  Court finds this evidence is relevant.  Probative value is not substantially outweighed by danger of unfair prejudice.  Court would not allow multiple officers to testify to this evidence.  Court finds that would be cumulative.  7)  Notes / memo books to be turned over ahead of time - Atty Leusink will send out a follow up to the Officers as to whether these records exist.  And if they do exist, they are to be turned over promptly to the State and then the State is to provide them to the defense.  To be submitted to defense by April 1st if they exist.  
8)  Order relating to any statements by the defendant to law enforcement officers.  If necessary court would have a Miranda/Goodchild motion.  Court schedules Miranda/Goodchild hearing - April 13, 2017 at 9:00 a.m. (1hour).  Court returns to 4) of the Motions in limine - Court has reviewed materials submitted by both the Defense and the State.  There has to be a factual basis to support a self-defense claim.  Atty Flynn provides offer of proof as to what her client would be testifying to at trial relating to self-defense.  Court needs to determine whether there is a basis to support self-defense.  Response by Atty Leusink.  Court cannot make a decision today as to whether the McMorris evidence is admissible.  Court thinks there needs to be a factual basis to support self defense before reputation and McMorris evidence can be presented.  Court believes it is a little premature at this point.  Response by Atty Flynn.  If Court makes finding that a factual basis has been raised to support self defense, reputation evidence can be used to establish victim's conduct.  Atty Flynn list witnesses she would call.  Court makes finding that prong 1 of analysis has been made.  Court addresses prong 2 of analysis;  Atty Flynn makes offer of proof as to what witnesses would say as to victim's reputation.  11:35 am  Response by Atty Leusink.  11:35 am  Response by Atty Flynn.  Court finds that 4 people testifying as to the same thing when they are all part of the same community is cumulative.  Court would expect the defense would limit this to 2 of these people who would give evidence or testify as to reputation / opinion.  
11:38 am  Court deals with McMorris motion.  Response by Atty Leusink to Court's questions as to his position.  Argument by Atty Flynn.  Court makes record as to when this can and cannot be asked of the victim by the defense.  Letters a, b and c do show specific instances of conduct by the victim with regard to violence / aggressive behalf.  Court believes they do meet the criteria under McMorris and are admissible to show her state of mind if self-defense is shown.  As to d, Court does not think that is the type of specific incident of conduct that would apply to McMorris evidence.  Court believes it would be unfairly prejudicial.  11:48 am  Argument by Atty Flynn.  Response by Atty Leusink.  Further argument by Atty Flynn.  11:53 am  Court makes further record and will not allow "d";  Court next addresses item "e" of motion;  Atty Flynn makes record with regard to incident involving "pulling the child's ponytail".  11:55 am  Response by Atty Leusink.  11:56 am  Court makes record that it preliminarily meets test for being relevant and might be probative and not outweighed by any unfair prejudice so Court will allow it.  
11:58 am  Atty Flynn makes regard with regard to defense motion to review victim's employee records.  Atty Flynn argues that these are not privileged records.  
12:02 pm  Response by Atty Leusink.  
12:03 pm  Court makes record and denies request as to employment records of victim.  
12:05 pm  Court in recess.
DA service fees - $160.00

Court in session at 2:01 pm. Defendant Jeffrey S McKenzie in court with attorney Francis R. Lettenberger.  Matthew Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
